71bd9426656c7068876f52fb7934af7f (00:22): phrased differently: I think I'm going to make a big interactive map of standards!
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:30): hello folks. The W3C validator gives me "Bad value for attribute action on element form: Must be non-empty." because I use <form action="" ..>

a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:31): the url is computed by the authentication engine and contains variable parameters. Is there any way to work around the validation error and still maintain a "post to current url" behavior?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:42): action="."
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:42): because "." means "this location"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:42): and ".." means "one dir up"
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:48): would that preserve parameters?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:48): which parameters
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:49): landing to http://site.com/path/?next=foo , would action="." send to http://site.com/path/?next=foo or just http://site.com/path/ ?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:49): the latter.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:49): if you want to preserve parameters, add them to your form using "<input type='hidden' name='monkey' value='banana'>"
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:49): why in the sky was this constraint introduced?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:49): you could write some JS to do this automatically based on window.location
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:50): because arguments are single time things
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:50): I will just ignore the validation outcome for that part.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:51): if I call "index.html?lol=rofl", then relative links are relative to my page. not to my page+args
eb3f49ff0e7508a6bd7e68a4f9ef04d4 (00:51): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b i never knew that about form action
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:52): action takes any legal URL, and "." and ".." are legal URLs for "this dir" and "parent dir"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:52): which is why action="index.html" and action="./index.html" do the same thing
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:53): a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726, if you have a form that needs to preserve the arguments, simply use a bit of JS to extend your form, or modify the action.

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:54): <form action="?I=maru"....> on a page "index.asp" will call index.asp?I=maru, for instance. So if you want to explicitly encode arguments that way, that's also fine
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:54): come to think of it, action=?" might even work, although I never tried that O_o
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:55): yes, when you want to break out of the default model for how HTML works, any recommendation I do involving "write some JS" is pretty serious =)
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:55): I think W3C has to revise that constraint, or introduce a conventional representative for "current URI"
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:55): most definitely, so I'll break it :)
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:56): exactly, so break it with well written JS
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:56): say I go to index.html?user=pomax
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:56): and there's a relative link to "test.html"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:56): where should it go? ./test.html?user=pomax?
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:56): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: I think both you and I have better ways to spend time :)
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:57): I don't know, you're asking a question, I'm answering it, if you think that's a waste of time, something went wrong =)
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:57): I think it's great that you have thorough and dedicated. And I think this constraint is short sighted
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:58): think of it this way: arguments are not HTML
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:58): and I represent industry, which cares about practicality. This is not practical, here's my answer to W3C: I'll just break it.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:58): they are instructions to the server.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:58): which means that your server can do something with them, to generate content.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:58): that includes making sure that content that needs to further use them in links, has them right there.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:59): it's your responsibility.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:59): if you're using PHP or something to accept those arguments, then you get to write the code to inject them into the form that gets generates for that page.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:59): it's pretty simple that way
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (00:59): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: short sighted. Think of a login form, where ?next=X is the landing page after it. Params are just the right way to do it
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (01:00): it has nothing to do with the page's own content, yet it needs to be passed on
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:00): you're missing the point. where do params *GO*
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:00): if you have plain html content, they don't go anywhere, argument parsing is not part of HTML, it's part of "server-side handling"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:00): so that's where you make the magic happen.
a20e0580519fa0e9092d058a67627726 (01:00): no doubt I can do it with machinery. I just deem it unpractical.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:01): and that's how new technology is born.
